job_title: PCA Float Pool in Worcester, MA
pros: Great communication, friendly staff, and as a student nurse like myself they have a fantastic new grad RN program. The hospital is also well funded which makes all the difference as well. One of if not the best hospital in central Massachusetts.
cons: It is a large hospital so if you prefer to work in a smaller facility maybe look elsewhere.

pros: great place to work at
cons: very hard work and can be too much

pros: Great hours. Love making my own schedule. I love how autonomous you can be here. Campus is beautiful. Parking is adequate. Dunkies inside the building. Has a union of course.
cons: Pay for PCA and tech is low. Nursing homes makes more. Have to take the shuttle if you’re newer. Could be good or bad depending on what you personally like. Have to pay for parking. $6 per paycheck. Everything goes by seniority (which hours you pick, parking, pretty much everything) which isn’t necessarily a con to me. It makes sense. Even newer managers have to take the shuttle.

pros: I have longevity in this organization and I see constant transformational change leading to measurable and verifiable improvements. Constant. That still means there are pockets of excellence and areas ripe for improvement - but for such a large organization to be striving for and achieving excellence for goal after goal after goal, it really helps to keep me motivated and optimistic about how this organization can make a difference for our patients and our community. The Lean culture is real and palpable. In particular, the COVID-19 response really highlighted the power of having an 'army of problem solvers'. UMass has been recognized nationally for its successes over the past few pandemic and post-pandemic years.
cons: So much of that empowering lean culture and striving for excellence is catalyzed or neutralized by the quality of middle management. This is true for clinical, medical, and administrative departments.

review_title: Dedicated to the Dr I Work For

review_title: BEST place to work, great culture, awesome managers, incredible benefits, work/life balance
pros: The culture is great at UMass Memorial Health. Lucky to work for such a wonderful organization.
cons: No negative things to say at this time.

pros: I feel like UMass has done their best to create a culture of transparency and valuing caregivers throughout COVID. We receive weekly email updates, throughout the pandemic they gave all caregivers several bonuses and an across the board 4% raise. The healthcare and benefits are BCBS of MA - I’ve found it great.
cons: They say they are committed to a more diverse and inclusive environment for staff and patients which is great - but there doesn’t seem to be a system to hold people who are not committed to those values accountable. They recently enacted a policy to protect staff from patient violence. I do think they try to make you feel like they care about their employees but they could go further with DEI efforts than just words and creating a DEI office

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Worcester, MA

cons: Healthcare is really busy, you just can't give enough. Take care of yourself to take care of your job, and in that order.

review_title: UMass Memorial Health is a GREAT Employer

pros: Everyone is a caregiver - this means that no matter what you do at UMass, you contribute to the care of our patients. We follow Standards of Respect - 6 key behaviors that all caregivers are asked to follow: Acknowledge, Listen, Communicate, Be Responsive, Be a Team Player and Be KIND. Good benefits Great people Good communication from leadership Pension plan
cons: Annual increases are the same for all.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Worcester, MA
pros: There are very few pros I can list. It was a good learning experience.
cons: I worked at UMass for several years. My floor (7 East) was chronically understaffed with high staff turnover rate. The MNA nursing contract is liberally interpreted by management. I felt like my license was at risk every day I went into work and feared for my patient's safety. I was not able to provide quality care in the environment they have created. More and more is constantly added to the list of the Nurse's responsibilities without removing any tasks to lighten the load.

review_title: Great culture, slow moving, not sure what it wants to be
pros:
-Inclusive culture and admirable organizational mission.
-Very good health insurance, good options for dental and other benefits.
-Decent PTO accrual.
-Flexible work schedule if needed.
-Friendly, helpful coworkers.
-Weekly pay.
-Leadership receptive to new ideas.

Despite the appearance of rigid structure and strong attempts at creating formal process, there is a lot of flexibility around the margins. If you're self-driven, motivated, and willing to inject yourself into tasks that aren't directly your job - you may find new opportunities for growth and recognition, and carve out an unique niche for yourself. Politics are heavily at play and some processes don't intuitively make sense but grew organically over time. Many people are willing to share information, and some are very receptive to help. 

There are many people working very hard to push the organization forward and some are just along for the ride. Some people in the wrong positions that are hindering progress as the organization tries to modernize.

IT Leadership is receptive to new ideas, however takes a long time to implement them in many cases. UMass is a large ship that takes time to steer, patience is required. Little will happen overnight unless there is an urgent need or a political influence from higher up.

UMass emphasizes a bottom-up idea system. Your mileage may vary with your manager, but the company does often change processes based on feedback from the people actually performing the work.
cons:
-Poor communication with duplication of efforts common, or starting projects over. Lots of wasted time.
-Ineffective project management team.
-Rigid change control. 
-Daily time tracking in multiple systems despite having a salaried position.
-Mediocre salaries.
-Low work expectations for some teams (this could be a pro if you aren't looking to grow professionally).
-No annual bonus.
-2% annual raise.
-24x7 healthcare organization , on-call commitment varies by IS team.
-Large company that takes a long time to steer.

They will work you until they use everything you have left
No appreciation 
Bad atmosphere 
Favoritism 
They’re into doing trainings that feel like MLM schemes - like LEAN
Do not appreciate loyalty or hard work

job_title: Ambulatory Services Representative in Worcester, MA
pros: 401k match, paid holidays off.
cons: so far there are no cons

pros: Managers care for employees. Good benefits.
cons: Employee parking, career advancement within the company

pros: Great Benefits while working here
cons: Morning shift can be competitive

review_title: HealthAlliance is a great place to work, but make sure you understand what your role and expectations are.
job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Leominster, MA
pros: Salaries are competitive with many of the hospitals in the area.  The people are great to work with, and are quite friendly.  It's a family environment.  The benefits package is great.  There is a lot of vacation/sick time, two types of health/dental plans, flexible spending account, and a 403b plan.  It's a good place to work if you like to be involved in many different aspects of health care technology.  If you aren't a clinical person, that knowledge will surely increase as a result of being employed.  The software vendors do on-site training, and are generally easy to work with.
cons: There isn't much room for advancement as groups are small, and there aren't many levels of management.  Management, at times is blind to what it takes to complete various tasks which can cause some frustrations.  24/7 support is necessary, and can cut into a personal life when being called during off-hours.  There is a lot of juggling which must be done, and a person must be very good at task management and prioritizing because tasks will get buried quickly, so organization is a must.  This can get frustrating because many tasks don't get finished and get left behind.  You must be a self-learner because the amount of useful training which is received is minimal.

pros: Co-workers are phenomenal, learned more than I ever thought I could.
cons: Schedule is terrible and probably won't change.

pros: Largest employer in central Massachusetts
cons: Job offerings limited for nurses unless member of union

review_title: An Organization in Transition (aka turning a ship)
job_title: Non-union Registered Nurse in Worcester, MA
pros: Many dedicated, long-term, employees.   Workplace diversity and a variety of opportunities.   World class research emerging from the affiliated medical school.   Academic medical center with a (potentially) bright future.   The talent within the organization is amazing.  Benefit packages are second to none; truly untouchable in the market these days.  The role of this organization within the surrounding community is HUGE.  Many opportunities to connect with volunteer opportunities.  When the organization is turned around it will return to its former glory.
cons: It does feel like constant firefighting (even in replacing staff who leave- see below regarding succession planning) and the goals and "must-do" (for safety) projects get triaged and potentially lost, which contributes to the employees' frustration.   Work-life balance for those who hold themselves accountable can be hard;  those who see it as only a job seem to have work-life balance figured out and can walk away at the end of the day.   Accountability and, occasionally, professionalism across the organization are lacking.

review_title: Good co workers, hospital wide changes hard on nurses
pros: Overall the people here are great and the patient care is generally good to very good.   They are willing to work with your schedule if any special needs come up.  Pay is competitive and better than a lot of nearby hospitals.
cons: Before the state ratio laws they were tripling up nurses in the ICU, floating to ER a lot without even a 5 minute orientation of how things work, where things are, etc... The EMR they use is time consuming and tedious, taking nurses away from the bedside for much of their shift, numerous charting systems throughout hospital, worst is Sorian, although purportedly they will be switching over to Epic at some point in the future.

pros:
-good team work
-good manager 
-flexible scheduling
cons: no bad experiences working with the hospital

pros: Excellent providers, mentors and attendings. Amazing learning and teaching opportunities.
cons: Nothing to add for cons

pros: Excellent wages compared to other hospitals.
cons: It is understaffed on all shifts.

pros: well educated nurses and critical care stat nurses for emergent needs
cons: constant switching of management without warning

pros: Good place to get experience
cons: One thing is that management needs work

pros: i like them a lot
cons: i am happy working with them

job_title: Provider Relations Representative in Worcester, MA
pros: Good work environment, supportive management.
cons: In office only work opportunity

review_title: Getting better but not there yet
pros: New management has made a lot of positive changes. Ideas boards have been implemented and Dept. Managers are highly encouraged to help get their employees ideas put into place. Better IT systems being implemented. Benefits are great but the ACA is killing that.
cons: Exempt employees are part of a Pay for Performance plan however the pool of money for increases is so low that the increases do not even keep up with the cost of living. Non Union employees have the opportunity to work OT, Managers and above receive annual bonuses but the exempt employees are stuck working long hours with little hope of a decent increase at the end of the year. You can get an outstanding review and still get the same percentage increase and the person sitting next to you who does the bare minimum required of them. Exempt employees also lost vacation time permanently during budget cuts a few years ago. Non exempt only gave up time for one year and union employees did not have to give up any. We need to give employees incentive  to work hard and move up in the organization.

pros: Good exercise, good coworkers, good company
cons: Salary is lacking, can be frustrating

pros: Good place to work with opportunities to learn.
cons: Growth opportunities may be for select few.

job_title: Injury Prevention Coordinator in Worcester, MA
pros: Flexibility in my schedule and ability to be creative with creating programs
cons: Lack of resources and staffing support

pros: Nice colleagues, very reasonsable management folks
cons: Patients rude to staff at times.

pros: Great Director, flexible hours, autonomy
cons: There are no cons that I can think of.

review_title: Good place to work - would be great if there were less politics
pros: The benefits at UMass are really good. Excellent health care, competitive PTO/sick leave, good low-cost day-care. The IT department is kept rather lean in its staffing levels, so there are enough avenues where a person can really take on new responsibility and carve their own path. It feels alot like a start-up company.
cons: Politics abound. Not just at the C-level, but permeating through all levels of the organization. Reviews and raises are arbitrary, not based at all on your performance but on the discretion of the manager. People get hired because of who they know, not necessarily because they are qualified. Any form of promotion, raise, advancement, or betterment within the organization can only come after a good deal of politicking and selling oneself. As a result, there is a good deal of personal drama that is exposed throughout the work day, often to an unprofessional extent.

pros: The pharmacy benefits are great. It is not located in Boston.
cons:
I agree with this previous quote.
 The pay is crap, raises are non-existent, and the drama is always more important than the task at hand. 

There are a number of group leads who just live on drama and try to blow everything out of proportion. For instance if you have a doctors appointment they start talking about family leave act.  And definitely don't have your back. In fact will actively throw you under the bus to hide their short comings, or sometimes I think just for their amusement. They will set you up to fail and not offer support and then gloat when you do fail.

I do actually agree with upper management and the direction they are trying to go in. It is farther down in the management chain where the issues are. At that level they seem to be stuck in 80's management styles.

If you do suggest better ways of doing something they double down on their approach even as their plan is burning down around them. Sometimes I feel I work in a kindergarten.

review_title: Excellent benefits, some really good staffers, confused management and goals often leading to extreme work overload.
pros: Serving a noble cause, excellent benefits, generally some great colleagues, and the opportunities to improve the health of others.
cons: Older management style with some dead woods that rose to their level of incompetence, hamping progress, stressing staff, and generating low confidence in their career paths.  High turnover of those there over 2+ years. Those who do the least, pass off tasks, and say 'yes' the most push out those of the highest value and integrity. Had to leave after 3 years to save my mental/physical health.

job_title: Strategy & Business Development Manager in Worcester, MA
pros:
Mission-based and patient-centered organization with excellent, highly-motivated senior leadership that is trying to reshape the culture of UMass. 

Large network of talented providers and a compassionate workforce.

Excellent benefits, fair compensation. 

"Lean" organization that trains staff in principle-based methodology that relies on a collaborative team effort to improve performance by systematically removing waste and reducing variation - highly valuable!
cons:
*Need for more fresh talent and new/relevant skill-sets.* 

Highly unionized staff, which limits flexibility in cross-training staff, strains financial resources, and creates inequality for non-unionized staff. Poor attitudes among some staff that impact the culture - lots of "complainers" and not enough "doers." 

Somewhat disjointed with community hospitals; need for more "systemness," which is something senior leadership is working on. 

Academic health care system, which can create access issues (lots of academic doctors and patients but few clinicians.) Need more non-academic physicians to improve access. 

Unpaid maternity leave.

review_title: Okay if you don't want hard work to pay off
pros: They offer great benefits although paid time off is earned rather than a set amount each year. The coworkers are great and make you feel like a part of the team.
cons: They leave positions unfilled for way to long even if it has been posted while expected people outside of the position to pick up the slack. They allow for nepotism making it really hard to effectively work and feel like you are not being held back when supervisors are allowed to promote their significant others.

review_title: Great place to work if your a college kid or someone looking for a high paying slave job.
job_title: Food Service Worker in Worcester, MA
pros: The Kitchen has a ton of awesome employees.  the pay is quite substantial, and holiday, weekend, and evening differentials allow for a huge pay boost.  no drug screening for all you potheads out there (hell yea!!!) Weekends are really easy since there is a small amount of staff/patients.  PLENTY of breaks, with the flow of work going from large amounts to nothing at all for even hours at times.
cons: poor management. poor maintenance, they seem to JUST keep things running around here.  dish machine breaks often and garbage disposals always fail.  we just work around it.  management sometimes chooses to ignore problems more often than fix them.  even if it means we could get shut down. example: the dish machine for 2 months was running at 60 degrees for its final rinse(instead of the industry standard of 180!). the supervisors would lie on the temp charts while we waited for parts. this is highly illegal.

pros: I have a wonderful Supervisor, my department has the potential to be great. Pay and benefits are good.
cons: Unfortunately, 99% of the people I have come in contact with  here say they hate their job and that it is a miserable place to work which leads to a negative work environment. Employees are encouraged to attend a "Standards of Respect" workshop which is ironic because the lack of basic respect people have for one another and the company itself is appalling. There is SO much drama within different departments, unlike I've ever seen.

review_title: Not the worst company to work for, but not the best.
pros: Fabulous benefits.  The starting pay was $20+ per hour for senior clerical workers.  Furthering your education is encouraged.  Should you be interested in another position within the company, you get special consideration.  First two years with this company are the best.
cons: After two years conditions go downhill.  Criticism is offered but praise is rare.  Overtime is frowned upon.  You cannot work longer than your allotted hours per week.  No matter how much work you have to do, you must get it done within your weekly hours.  Computer problems are always something that has to be dealt with.

pros: Co-workers, access to current medical information and protocols, salary for union workers.
cons: Turnover of leadership, top heavy with VP's all making too much money and getting bonuses off the work of their employees, no incentive to learn, salary for non-union employees. The union nurses get raises guaranteed raises and too many nurses take advantage of that.  Union is very strong and therefore nurses get away with way too much with no consequences for their actions.  Lack of respect and professionalism throughout the company.  Too much favoritism, treatment among employees with the same jobs is not equal,   some people required to work weekends and holidays and other are not.

pros: It's a great place to work if your looking for advancement opportunities. The pay rates are pretty good and the benefits are great. Most of the staff are pretty friendly across all departments.
cons: Some of the management need to be retrained or coached on how to properly manage a staff and processes of work flow.

job_title: Food Service Worker in Kingston, NY
pros: We all can find common ground in that the management in the department is awful so there is a sense of brotherhood among us underlings.
cons: We are talked down to by management and are rarely given a full time position with the benefits we should be given for the hours worked. they have different levels of "part time" work that they would rather stick you in. Rarely is anyone properly trained. There is very few chances to move up anywhere from starting position.

review_title: I loved working at UMass Memorial Medical Laboratories
pros: Treat teams - willing to work together to solve problems.  Caring leadership in the laboratory, wanted to have a great place to work.  My days were busy, but not overly long unless there was a problem. Work/life balance was easy to achieve.
cons: When the hospital decided to sell of the lab I knew that it was time to go.  I was very sad to see the laboratory sold off to Quest Diagnostics.  The hospital had a great revenue stream that they did not know how to handle.

pros: The benefits and pay are really good, and there is generous amounts of PTO time in addition to observing several holidays depending on your position and union affiliation.
cons: Lots of micromanaging which is completely unnecessary. We know our daily job responsibilities yet we get constant daily reminders. Management doesn't listen or communicate. Morale has really gone down.  Management does not respect or trust employees.

review_title: Management is in "la-la land" at this place
pros: Most of the average folks who work here are fine, and some are extraordinary. This review is about management, which is not fine, and is most certainly not extraordinary.
cons: I work at a facility owned by and ostensibly managed by UMMHC. I've been there for many years. I have NEVER seen any evidence of active management at either the corporate or the site level (except for constant 'rah-rah' email newsletters. To make matters worse, upper mgmt has subscribed to a program similar to LEAN/Six Sigma, which to my mind is no better than fascist brain-washing (based on positive thinking and failure to recognize real problems). I am only still there because I would have to drive a long way to find a similar job. Despite being 50+ I am now seeking to enter a completely different field which pays a lot less, simply so I can work in a better place.  Lastly, the discrepancy between executive salaries (stratospheric) and ordinary salaries (subterranean) at this place is truly alarming.

review_title: I generally expected more professionalism from higher up but was very disappointed with there work ethics
pros: The pros would be there benefits there great and reasonably priced
cons: The cons would be the miss management I experienced as well as the turn around rate

job_title: Clinical Applications Analyst in Worcester, MA
pros: Ability to move to different applications, lots of work, work/life balance, people  that you support are great, physicians, RN's are all willing to learn technology.
cons: Unable to move ahead, merit increases are small, management is controlling, mico-management, no ability to think and make decisions based upon situation, Anillary team fell apart and all new hires are on board.  New Soarian system has a significant amout of downtime which impacts the ancillary departments.  Not sure why they chose to move from Meditech to Soarian when a majority of large orginizations are going to Epic.

review_title: Constantly understaffed, otherwise good place to work
job_title: Critical Care Technician in Leominster, MA
pros:
Good coworkers, good local EMS/FD, ED camaraderie
Good pay
Flexible scheduling
cons:
Constantly understaffed
Out of touch management
Old equipment

pros: One of the largest hospital systems in the country. Resources are available to conduct very forward-thinking programs. There are some visionary thinkers who want to bring the system into the 21st century.
cons: The system was formed through acquisitions over many years.  The management structure of the original entities remains largely intact with no central oversight.  Leads to a lot of overlap in responsibilities and miscommunication.

review_title: Central Intake Admin Associate - Home Health and Hospice
job_title: Central Intake Administrative Associate in Leominster, MA
pros: The people are really nice and enjoyable to work with, the day flies by since there is always work to do, benefits are also good.
cons: There was no actual training - I had to learn on my own and only received feedback via trial by error. A lot of long nights and working lunches were involved in order to complete the workload for the sake of patient care.

pros:
dedicated people 
good pay, beneftis 
some semblence of structure in work
cons: very autocratic management.   too much micro management.    Don't apply fairness rules across all employees.   Some treated as favorites, others ignored or given more work.   Too much fire fighting going on with IS.   Continuous production issues in IS.     Need a better system of accountability and quality control.

review_title: Everyone needs to experience a professional hardship in their career
pros: Friendly people. The work environment is community spirited as well as being community oriented within Worcester. Laudable outreach programs which were fun to participate in.
cons: Tactical, firefighting with either no time or ability to see beyond the present. Administration which is inefficient and change resistant with senior management thinking that balancing the books can be achieved by simply continuing to cut the workforce.

pros: The great pay!  Good benefits.  Lots of patients to care for.
cons: Human Resources and Management does not support the employees as advertised on their website.  They will lie and make up stories to get their point across. They have the attitude of shoot through the door first and then open it to see what is on the other side, with no care or concern whose career they kill!

review_title: Excellent job, wish I was still working there!
job_title: Supply Coordinator I in Worcester, MA
pros: High pay scale, Union job, good health benefits package, liberal time off policy, are just some of the pros of working at UMassMemorial.
cons: Disagreements between co-workers are not solved. No good problem resolution system in place to resolve problems between co-workers.The only system in place is for disputes between workers and management, union is not set up for,and can't effectively resolve, disputes between union co-workers. This problem needs to be addressed.

pros: Even though they are shrinking, there are still great and competitive benefits
cons: Salary, and the current directors of pharmacy are not to be trusted.  They are expected to retire within the next five years, which may drastically improve the

review_title: Mismanaged finanically therefore they treat their employees terribly, especially the RNs
pros: Level 1 trama center in central ma.
cons:
They have scaled there education back for RNs because of a lack of funds.
They do not value their employees and are trying to pull back on benefits to save money.
Severe micromanagement and zero autonomy. Ranked the worse Emergency Dept in the state of MA. Vascular surgery dept unsafe.
If umass had their way they would hire uneducated individuals from 3rd world country's so they would not pay them. Equivalent to sweatshop mentality of patient care.

pros: There really aren't many pros except for having a job that pays a decent amount and having some benefits. They are great at hiding behind a friendly facade, so that's a plus.
cons: Management is under-handed and manipulative. Many issues don't get resolved. Communication is lacking. Gossip is rampant. Benefits are dwindling.

review_title: The job and working with the patients was great. Working with my supervisor and few employees was like school again...
pros: The patients, the busy environment, some of the friends I made, always learning something new.
cons: My supervisor and a few employees had their little posse and would shun and pick on whoever wasn't in it.

pros: Can't think of any except for the free coffee
cons: Complete lack of leadership, no transparency.  There are maybe two good managers, the rest have no clue what their own employees are doing and spend most of their time arguing with each other.  The pay is crap,  raises are non-existent, and the drama is always more important than the task at hand.  If you want to set your career back five years while working for a boss that you detest, this is the place to be.  Once their Epic project reaches the go-live date, they are in for a rude awakening.

review_title: Take better care of your employees.
job_title: Senior Network Engineer in Worcester, MA
pros: The people I worked with were great.
cons: No salary increases for the 7 years I was there while the executives made on average 70% increases year to year. Work load exponentially increased but compensation did not and staff did not.

job_title: Emergency Room Tech in Worcester, MA
pros: Great benifits, insurance is cost affective, 401 k. They have a decent pension plan as well.  Sick Benifits are also good with good vacation time
cons: Lousy management. Seems that there are more in leadership rolls, and much less in staff. Need of more nurses and techs. Need more respect!

review_title: Vice President, Marketing, Communications and Development
job_title: Vice President, Marketing, Communications and Development in Marlborough, MA
pros: A community hospital that has a long history of caring for the residents of the community and the community supports the hoapital. Member of UMass Memorial Health Care, largest health care system in Central MA.
cons: Challenges in health care.  State and federal cuts,  Labor costs continue to increase, yet reimbursements continue to decrease.  Very competitive market.

review_title: Lengthy hiring process but worth it!
job_title: Patient Access Representative in Worcester, MA
pros: Great pay and benefits, friendly coworkers/management, opportunities for advancement and ability to change hours or transfer positions within the company.
cons: Hiring process takes awhile. Took 2 months from when I applied to actually starting to work.

review_title: No support for employees; no work life balance
pros: Great benefit/benefit options but premiums are high. Easy commute from city.
cons: No work-life balance or support from management. Salaried employees aren't "expected" to work more than 40-45 hours, but the workload is so high you consistently do ~60 hours a week. Conflicting priorities and no clear direction from management. Very much a blame environment instead of working as a team. Staff retention is low for a reason. No pathway for moving up in the organization.

job_title: Blood Bank Medical Technologist in Worcester, MA
pros: Very nice facility! and the salary was very good too!
cons: Too many open shifts do to lack of night shift personnel . Covering nights shifts while working on day shift  was unhealthy and a dangerous drive... having to come at 3 am. Only good if you want to make a lot of money working overtime.

review_title: Low pay, employees are micro-managed, it's a wonder that anything gets done with so many meetings.
pros: Met some great people, decent vacation time.
cons: Terrible pay.  Work load doubled after a hiring freeze was put into place with no extra compensation. Different rules apply to different employees - double standard.  Always have to watch your back.  Plan on leaving for work at least 45 minutes earlier than expected due to the parking issues (and bring an extra coat for when you have to wait outside for a shuttle in the winter).

review_title: The benefits are good, but the work schedule makes it tough to have a life.
pros: The benefits are good, especially the accrued time off policy.  It really allows you flexibility with time off for vacations, sickness, etc.
cons: Having to work every third weekend makes it tough to have a life.  It's tough raising a family when you have to constantly switch days off with other employees.

pros:
Wonderful management
Current push toward better work atmosphere
See a lot of care for patients
Lots of experience garnered
cons:
HUGE company, can feel dehumanizing
Also see a lot of disregard for patients (company too big)

pros: This organization offers good dental and health benefits
cons: Respiratory Care Department's management does not stand behind their subordinates. They under-staff and increase patient care loads to very unsafe levels for both patients and staff! Management expects staff therapists to do multiple treats at one time: unsafe! Doctors, nurses and respiratory work against each other. No team approach to patient care, even though management thinks there is; the culture is 'back-stabbing'! Disconnected disciplines: Unsafe!

review_title: Great benefits and a wonderful new CEO!
pros: Great compensation, health insurance, and 401K match. The new CEO is very inspiring and really helping to improve the culture.
cons: Too many unions making it hard or impossible for managers to promote the best talent. It is a shame to promote based solely on seniority.

pros: Not many. Free Jackets every two years.
cons: The upper management is awful, it's always the clinics faults. Scheduling pod is crazy, they don't even know how to ask a few important questions (i.e. Which side & where it hurts, getting correct contact info). Also the HIPPA voilations EVERYWHERE. Don't be fooled!

job_title: CANCER CENTER COORDINATOR in Worcester, MA
pros: The only pros I can think of is the Union negotiates pay raises although the staff is really underpaid.
cons: Staff is micromanaged.  The Management do not want to hear concerns or deal with any Issues that may Arise.

review_title: Great place for a career I  healthcare
pros: Nice Shift differential , excellent benefits and lots of room to grow.
cons: Training specific to some positions can be better.   Most co-workers where nosy and always gossiping and talking at each others back, environment was definitely not great but the company itself was.

pros: Large organization, excellent benefits, good pay, lots of opportunity for advancement, great patient care
cons: Very unionized. Union created a barrier between employees and supervisors. Sometimes the most qualified people got passed over for those with more seniority.

review_title: Bad Management; Preferential treatment to Favorites
job_title: Medical Administrative Float in Worcester, MA
pros: Competitive pay, great benefits, wonderful colleagues who work hard and are very supportive; people who really care about their job.
cons: Managers who give preferential treatment to favorites, including letting their favorites get away with pretty much anything, hiring them as managers, etc.

job_title: Senior Contract Manager in Worcester, MA
pros: Great Healthcare Benefits, Earned Time can be cashed out.  Decent Vacation time.
cons: Senior Management is difficult to deal with.  Lack of room to grow.  Very politically driven organization.  Terrible retirement plan.

pros: Good benefits and pension, health insurance coverage is very good based on the number of employees.
cons: Administration is too powerful and top heavy.  The care is no longer patient based, it is profit based.

pros: Ease of access, low cost parking
cons:
On the University Campus, 
-Per-Diem RNs  are all paid a flat rate irregardless of years of experience, work experience, etc.
-When you join as a part-time or full-time nurse after working somewhere else, they drop your salary behind the years of experiences.

pros: Ability to be self directed, can use creativity, great management team.  There is a lot of longevity of staff, community feel to hospital
cons: Pto is bundled with no possibility of carry over of any hours. Very lean, everyone wears many hats. Pay is average

job_title: Executive Administrative Assistant in Worcester, MA
pros: Interacting with the public and associating with some astounding healthcare providers. Health Benefits options are endless.
cons: Retirement plan match is AWFUL. The hospital/school does not invest in their employees, and their is very little done to show appreciation. You are just another number within the company.

pros: Nice people, nice environment and sense of pride when you work at UMass
cons: Very hard to move around in the organization

pros: Excellent pay.  Gain a broad base of experience.
cons: The multiple critical demands mean that you often cannot give the kind of patient care your would like to give.

pros: Half price on food, free coffe and fountain drinks. You get to interact with a lot of people that could help you later on in life.
cons: Can get very busy. Poor management, and communications. Needs a better training program

pros: Benefits package is better than most with 10 paid holidays per year.
cons: Too often they promote from within based on "like " and not merit.

pros: Benefits, salary is competitive, 401K with match and pension plan
cons: PTO is inadequate for starting positions, inconsistent management styles, union/nonunion shop makes for challenging workplace

pros: Great pay, time and a half after 8 hours, holiday pay time and a half. Every other weekend and holiday
cons: Not the cleanest hospital, small critical care unit. Small hospital In general. Newer nurses. Some units updated, small pediatric unit.

review_title: Decent opportunity to advance if you have the right licenses
pros: The coworkers made for a nice work atmosphere
cons: Union vs non union sometimes created uncertainties between management and employees

review_title: Overall I had a positive experience.
pros: The people are the best reason to work here.
cons: Large organization with a lot of layers.

pros: great health insurance, good employee benefits/perks
cons: growing pains - the organization is trying to do a lot in a very short period of time

review_title: great place to work at. awesome work environment
pros: a facility that really cares about patients and employees. works hard to  always improve and deliver the best
cons: the pay rates can be higher, with better compensations

pros: Hours were good, the commute wasn't bad
cons: authority figures created issues, fingerpointing, sketchy, and formed an unfair work environment

pros:
The pay is excellent
Benefits are the best that I have had from any company and very reasonably priced
cons:
Hard to move up unless you know someone 
inconsistent direction from leadership

pros: A lot of shifts are available for making a flexible schedule, management doesn't hover.
cons: Pay is equivalent to fast food work. At $12.XX I'm expected to perform care for sick patients yet I can get $12.XX + tips bussing tables.

pros:
-Great learning experience while in college
-Very helpful employees who were interested in getting you involved and valued your help
cons:
-Very low hourly wage given the type of work and time commitment
-Not a very youthful environment

pros:
Opportunity to help a lot of people when you focus on the patient experience
Many great new programs
cons: As with any large organization, bureaucracy can be a challenge.

pros: Major growth phase, easy to rise if you are capable, good work life balance
cons: Growing pains. EMR still being implemented, needs better coordination with community practices.

job_title: Patient Care Associate in Worcester, MA
pros:
Employee Programs
Education Opportunities 
Patient Acuity
ER is very busy, hard work, but rewarding
cons: None at this time, sorry

pros: Nice people, great benefits, close to home.
cons: Despite whatever skills and education you acquire over time, they really want you to stay in the same job forever.

pros: The company offers awesome benefits, especially prescription drugs.
cons: If you aren't a nurse, you won't get the recognition you deserve. Non-clinical staff are extremely undervalued

job_title: Lead Laboratory Tech in Worcester, MA
pros: Still trying to figure that out

Medical coverage isn't comparable to other hospitals
Colleagues and managers should be better qualified
Little room for advancement

pros: Senior Management and the team is fully engaged in patient satifaction
cons: Too many layers to get things done

pros: Higher pay scale than most
cons: Disorganized. Bad financial decisions cost many their jobs in this area.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Dudley, MA
pros: Good benefits and pay. Good amount of earned time off. Friendly co workers. Reimbursement of educational cost for some courses, classes.
cons: Condescending attitude my management. Hard to get time off. No room for growth within department. Many staff members are allowed to do a minimum of work while others are expected to pick up the slack.

pros: Excellent collaboration between units and departments. Competitive wage. Great benefits
